{{short description|Constellation}}
'''Seven Stars''' is a common symbol throughout [[Arda]].

It refers to the constellation that turns through the northern skies every night of the year. To the [[Elves]] this was the [[Valacirca]] that signalled the downfall of [[Morgoth]],<ref>{{S|Captivity}}</ref> but the [[Men]] of the [[Northern lands]] called it simply '[[Valacirca|The Wain]]'.<ref>{{H|Welcome}}</ref> The Seven Stars are today known as the Plough, or the Big Dipper.

The [[Doors of Durin]] also displayed seven stars with a crown, probably representing [[Durin's Crown]].

The Seven Stars were also a symbol of [[Elendil]]: The [[Faithful]] escaped the [[Akallabêth]] on [[Elendil]]'s nine ships.<ref>{{S|Akallabeth}}</ref> Of those nine, each of the seven which carried one of the [[Palantíri]] had a single five-rayed star on its sail.<ref>{{HM|RC}}, citing from J.R.R. Tolkien's notes for the entry Elendil in the index of the George Allen & Unwin second edition of ''The Lord of the Rings'' from 1966, p. 436</ref> When [[Narsil]] was reforged, in [[Andúril]]'s blade were traced seven stars, set between a crescent Moon and a rayed Sun.<ref>{{FR|II3}}</ref> In the [[Rhymes of Lore|Rhyme of Lore]] remembered by [[Gandalf]], they are mentioned along with the seven ''[[Palantíri]]''.<ref>{{TT|III11}}</ref> The [[Crown of Gondor]] bore seven jewels of adamant set in the circlet.<ref>{{RK|VI5}}</ref>
